garrett_reminiscing.speaker: Narrator
garrett_reminiscing.text: Garrett sits at his usual table, a cup of tea growing cold before him. He stares at something only he can see.

garrett_starts.speaker: Old Man Garrett
garrett_starts.text: *He notices you approaching and smiles sadly* Forgive me. I was somewhere else. Fifty years ago, to be precise. Our first home.

garrett_story.speaker: Old Man Garrett
garrett_story.text: Eleanor and I... we met when we were young. She was a baker's daughter. Could make bread that tasted like sunshine. We had nothing, but we had everything.

garrett_young.speaker: Old Man Garrett
garrett_young.text: *His voice grows distant* Fifty-two years we had together. She made our little house a home. Every meal was a celebration, she said. Even the simple ones.

player_respond_memories.speaker: Narrator
player_respond_memories.text: What do you say to Garrett?

choices.text: She sounds wonderful. Thank you for sharing her with me.
Do you still cook her recipes?

garrett_appreciative.speaker: Old Man Garrett
garrett_appreciative.text: *He pats your hand* She was wonderful. And she's not truly gone, you know. Every time I taste honey in bread, I remember her laugh. That's a kind of living on.

garrett_hesitant.speaker: Old Man Garrett
garrett_hesitant.text: *His hands tremble slightly* Cook them? No. No, I... I can't. I've tried. But every time I start, I hear her voice guiding me, and I... *he trails off*

garrett_photo.speaker: Old Man Garrett
garrett_photo.text: *He pulls a worn photograph from his pocket* This is her. Taken on our anniversary, year forty-five. She said she finally liked how she looked in pictures.

garrett_tearful.speaker: Old Man Garrett
garrett_tearful.text: *His voice catches* I still set two places at the table every night. Foolish, I know. But I'm not ready to set just one.
